title: What are renewable energy resources? - Quora

response.answer_text: RE: What are innovative renewable energy resources? There are a whole lot of people who have been working on this for a long time so there is not much room for true innovation. Mostly smallish incremental improvements of various sorts rule “renewable energy” research these days. However I can think of one true innovation which would turn the energy debate on its head and in favor of “renewable energy”: an efficient, stable catalyst which would split water (H2O) into hydrogen and oxygen using the energy in sunlight. Plants do this all the time. People think plants split CO2 and give off the oxygen. Nope. Plants split water, H2O, give off the oxygen and attach the hydrogen to CO2 to make sugars for energy storage. That process powers almost all life on earth. Using sunlight to efficiently split water would overcome one of the biggest deficits of “renewable energy”, ie it is intermittent but we cannot store electricity cheaply. But we CAN store hydrogen cheaply. Such a catalyst would be a game changer. Note my repeated use of the word “efficient”. The other big problem with “renewable energy” is that it is diffuse energy. You need a lot of collectors when you are talking about supplying energy on a national scale, so a catalyst which would, say, use 1% of the energy in sunlight to make hydrogen simply would not cut it. I don’t know exactly where “game changer” lies in between 1% and 100% efficient, but it’s in there somewhere. Hmm, as far as I know no one is using large-scale solar cell farms to drive electrolysis of water to make hydrogen. That means that the “game changer” efficiency has got to be more than that process, ie . . . Solar cell energy conversion efficiencies for commercially available multicrystalline Si solar cells are around 14-19%. the industrial production of hydrogen, and using current best processes for water electrolysis (PEM or alkaline electrolysis) which have an effective electrical efficiency of 70-80% . . . more than 19% times 80% = 15% efficient. You might think that the 2 stage process of PV + electrolysis would cost more than a catalyst breaking apart water, but the catalyst would produce an explosive 2 hydrogens to 1 oxygen ratio gas which would have to be separated carefully without any possibility of igniting it. That separation process would use more energy, so my bet is that the “game changer” efficiency of a catalytic system would need to be WAY over 15%. But, if you do invent a sufficiently efficient, sunlight powered catalyst to split water then you will become a zillionaire (unless someone who has lots of money and fancy lawyers steals your formula or patent).  Addendum: I talk about catalysts above. I should also include any other process which efficiently produces hydrogen from sunlight and water, tho I do not know what that might be at this time.
